titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Annie Burr Lewis Papers
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 18, 2019 at 01:01

did.abstract: The collection contains correspondence, personal and family papers, and financial records that document the life, interests, and work of the American philanthropist Annie Burr Auchincloss Lewis (1902-1959).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence, 1900-1959 II. Personal Papers, 1902-1958. III. Family Papers, 1849-1955. IV. Financial Records, 1926--1959. V. American Red Cross Records, 1941-1946.

bioghist.head: Annie Burr Lewis (1902-1959)
bioghist.p: Annie Burr Auchincloss Lewis was born in Newport, Rhode Island, on July 22, 1902, the daughter of Emma Jennings Auchincloss and Hugh Dudley Auchincloss. She attended Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Connecticut, and married Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis in New York in 1928. She died in Hartford, Connecticut, on May 9, 1959.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Annie Burr Lewis Papers. The Lewis Walpole Library, Yale University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated Material: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20). The Lewis Walpole Library.
Associated Material: Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs (LWL MSS 22). The Lewis Walpole Library.
Associated Material: Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform (WONPR), Connecticut Division Financial Records (LWL MSS 24). The Lewis Walpole Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, personal and family papers, and financial records that document the life, interests, and work of the American philanthropist Annie Burr Lewis (1902-1959). The correspondence is with her mother Emma Brewster Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942), her aunt Annie Burr Jennings (1855-1939), and nieces, nephews, and cousins in the Auchincloss and Jennings family, as well as her friends from childhood, school, and adult life. Personal papers include her appointment books, awards, recipe books, school notebooks, scrapbooks and postcard albums, and family papers consist of genealogical materials documenting branches of the Auchincloss and Jennings families. Her financial records cover both her personal banking and investments. The last series holds records from Annie Lewis's service with the American Red Cross as assistant director for Volunteer Special Services (1941-1944) and Volunteer Field Representative for Camp and Hospital Service (1944-1946) in Connecticut.

Family papers also include materials related to the lives and estates of Emma Jennings Auchincloss and Annie Burr Jennings, plus a group of letters to Jennings from William Howard Taft, and inscribed portrait photographs of Taft and Benito Mussolini.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Printed material found with the collection was removed for separate cataloging and can be accessed by searching the library's online catalog.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Annie Burr Lewis Papers is the physical property of the Lewis Walpole Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the W. S. Lewis Librarian/Executive Director.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

controlaccess.subject: Cooking, American
Women philanthropists
controlaccess.corpname: Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Family, Friends and Colleagues, and Service and Affiliations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence that had been kept separate from the enormous quantity of correspondence received by Wilmarth and Annie Lewis that now forms Series I in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20). Most of the letters here were addressed solely to Annie Lewis by members of the Auchincloss and Jennings family, her personal friends, and staff at organizations with which she was involved as a volunteer or donor. It is unclear who made the separation of these materials, but in their isolation they do set facets of Annie Lewis's life apart from the panorama of the Lewises' social and academic connections and activities.

The Family Correspondence subseries holds letters from Annie Lewis's Auchincloss and Jennings siblings, aunt, cousins, and their children, and correspondence with her mother Emma Brewster Auchincloss (1861-1942) and favorite aunt Annie Burr Jennings (1855-1939). Though she was very generous to, and interested in, all of her nieces, nephews, and their children, Annie Lewis developed closer relationships with Edmund, Emma Anita, and John Nash, the children of her sister Esther (1895-1986) and her first husband Edmund W. Nash (1896-1947). The three spent their childhood in the New York area prior to moving to Reno, Nevada, in 1929 for Esther Nash's divorce, and remaining in the West after she married Norman Biltz (1902-1973) in 1930. Also filed here are six folders of letters sent between Annie Lewis and her husband, most written while he was away on travels or she was in Virginia attending business meetings at Mount Vernon. There is one letter present from Wilmarth Lewis's brother George describing the camera equipment he had sent her; all other communications with the Lewis family are filed in Series I of Wilmarth Lewis's papers (LWL MSS 20).

The second subseries, Friends and Colleagues, holds letters from former Farmington schoolmates and a group of suitors Annie Lewis had attracted in the early and mid-1920s. Among the latter were the explorer Varick Frissell (Yale 1926) who wrote from the snowy Grenfell Mission in Labrador, and Walter Rumsey Marvin (Yale 1922), who signed his ardent poetic tributes "Rummy" and wisely chose a career path away from creative writing. Her schoolmates included the thrice-married adventurer Anna Hope Dale Biddle Burgess Glidden (1902-1984), known as "Nannie," whose more than fifty letters to Annie Lewis narrate the second half of her peripatetic life. She left her husband and children in suburban Philadelphia for the charismatic naval designer W. Starling Burgess, and when that marriage foundered, Burgess left her scrambling to support herself through a series of jobs that included day labor on a farm, "slinging six lb pans" of frozen food in a New Jersey factory, selling skin care products on commission for Beauty Counselors Inc., and organizing a wool weavers cooperative in rural Maine. The letters in Series I show that Nannie, though resouceful, was just one of several friends—and family members—to whom Annie Lewis regularly provided seemingly unflagging moral, material, and financial support. As Nannie wrote to Wilmarth Lewis in 1976, "despite how different we were she always seemed to understand, which was more than most did." Letters from Starling Burgess explain the engineering projects for which he too sought backing, as do those from Olivia Heminway Kammerer whose school in Florence exposed young American women to Italian art and culture. Annie Lewis also supported many tradesmen, and filed here are correspondence and photographs from the paintings conservator Morton Bradley and furniture makers/restorers of the Nathan Margolis Shop, both concerning art and antiques she owned.

The third subseries, Services and Affiliations, holds correspondence with organizations and institutions with which Annie Lewis worked over her lifetime. Prominent among these is the First Church of Christ, Congregational, in Farmington, and the files contain documentation of the several committees on which she served. Perhaps her most significant contribution was to the Restoration Committee which undertook a six-year project to raise and return the pulpit and sounding-board to their original location on the east wall; its success is marked by a plaque on the church wall acknowledging her effort. Annie Lewis's devotion to the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union was inspired by that of her aunt Annie Burr Jennings, who served as the third Vice Regent for Connecticut from 1915 to her death in 1939. Yale University was the focus of Annie Lewis's greatest philanthropic efforts through her establishment of Special Fund "L," the Annie Burr Lewis Fund, and the Lewis-Farmington Trust. Because the funds continued and were monitored long after her death by her husband, the existing records are in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20), Series VII, Boxes 324-325. However, filed here is documentation of Annie Lewis's work with the university's Medical Affairs Committee, School of Nursing, and Yale University Art Gallery, as well as the records of her extensive involvement with the Faculty Committee for Receiving Oxford and Cambridge University Children during World War II. Included there is a painted bowl that was a gift from of one of the young refugees whose family Annie Lewis sponsored during their stay in Farmington.

Readers seeking to explore Annie Burr Lewis's network of friends and colleagues must also check the extensive correspondence files in Series I of the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20), as no attempt was made to remove from that collection letters addressed only to her.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Emma Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942), the mother of Annie Burr Lewis, married Hugh Dudley Auchincloss (1858-1913) in 1891. Papers related to her life, interests, and estate are filed in Series III. Family Papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hugh Dudley Auchincloss Jr. (1897-1976) was the brother of Annie Lewis, and like her, a summer resident at Hammersmith Farm in Newport, Rhode Island. Auchincloss was also a financial investments manager for the Lewises, so additional correspondence with him can be found in Series IV, Financial Records.

did.unittitle: Auchincloss, Hugh ("Yusha") D. Jr. and Alice

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hugh Dudley ("Yusha") Auchincloss III (1927-2015) was the son of Annie Lewis's brother Hugh D. Auchincloss (1897-1976) and his first wife Maria Nikolayevna Chrapovitsky (1899-1990).

did.unittitle: Auchincloss family birthday card for Annie Lewis, drawn by Jacqueline Bouvier

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The celebrants saluting "Aunt Abie" in this birthday greeting are the children of Hugh and Janet Auchincloss, and were identified in a pencil inscription by Wilmarth Lewis; his notations on the verso assign authorship and a date of July 22, 1946. A sketch on the verso shows the couple's standard poodles presenting a birthday cake to Wilmarth and Annie Burr Lewis, aunt and uncle of the artist, whose enthusiasm for Walpole is humorously alluded to with a sign at the foot of the bed that reads "Horace Walpole Slept Here."
The card is framed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains letters from other members of the Biltz family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings concerning Sarah Porter, the founder of Miss Porter's School, and her school's centenary celebration.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Arthur Murray Dodge (1913-1974) was the first husband of Anita Nash, and the brother of Annie Lewis's close friend Josephine Dodge Kimball.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folder primarily holds letters and drawings from the children of Anita and Arthur Dodge; also present is a photostat of a draft letter written in 1955 from Annie Lewis to Annie Burr Auchincloss Dodge on the topic of their namesake Annie Burr Jennings.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Emma Anita Nash (1922-2011), known to the family as "Buddy," was the eldest daughter of Annie Lewis's sister Esther Auchincloss and a favorite niece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folder also holds correspondence with psychiatrist Dr. John A. P. Millet regarding his work with Anita Dodge between the dissolution of her marriage to Arthur Dodge and her wedding to the author Philip Harkins (1914-1997).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Annie Burr Jennings (1855-1939) was the aunt of Annie Lewis. Papers related to her life, interests, and estate are filed in Series III. Family Papers. In addition, many of the postcards found in the albums in Series II, Personal Papers, were sent by Annie Jennings during her European travels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter from Luke Lockwood to Annie Lewis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes one letter from the Lewises' friend Moreau Delano, dated December 11, 1927.

did.unittitle: Nash, Edmund ("Ted") W., Jr., and Ruth Coffin

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edmund W. Nash Jr. (1918-2004), the first-born of Annie Lewis's several nephews and nieces, was son of her sister Esther Auchincloss Nash. He married Ruth Prentice Coffin (1921-2007) in 1941; an artist, she was the daughter of Dorothy Prentice and Henry Sloan Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary in New York. Nash served in North Africa and Italy with the United States Army during World War II. Though they lived in California, the Nashes remained close to the Lewises and would often spend time at "The Castle" in Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leaf specimens collected in Newport and arranged by Ruth Coffin Nash. Also present is an undated hand-lettered label for "The Nash Beach-Glass Collection," likely from a display left behind after the family had visited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The two narrative poems written and illustrated by Ruth Nash were likely created as notes of appreciation after the Nash family had visited the Lewises.

did.unittitle: Nash, Ruth Coffin: photostats of ink sketches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Formerly in a brown paper wrapper inscribed by Annie Lewis: "RPN's drawings / Ruth Prentice Nash (Mrs. E. W. Nash) photostats of drawings sent E.W.N. when he was in Italy during the war, 1943-45."

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Nash (1921-2008) was the son of Esther and Edmund Nash, and raised his own family in the West.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folder also contains a 1954 letter to Annie Lewis from Catherine Auchincloss, enclosing a Newport-related letter to her from her cousin William A. Paton, dated November 15, 1919, which Lewis had sent on to Alice Brayton, and Brayton then returned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his letter Chamberlain agrees to take photographs of the interior and exterior of the Cowles House, the Lewises's home in Farmington, which he would have printed as "contact postcards" in Boston. The resulting negatives are in Series V of the Lewises' photograph collection (LWL MSS 22), Box 10, folder 3, and two sets of postcards are in Wilmarth Lewis's papers (LWL MSS 20), Box 33, folder 8, and Box 277, folder 2.

Also present here is a brochure advertising Chamberlain's "The American Scene" postcard series published by the Yale University Press, four printed postcards including a view of the Cowles House, and an uncut sheet of postcards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also present is a snapshot photograph of Annie Lewis that Frissell enclosed in one of his letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Annie Burr Lewis to Hudson, and one to Hudson from Andre Mankowsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filed here is correspondence documenting Mabel Hurlburt's work to create an historical census of Farmington homes and properties, a project underwritten by Annie Lewis. The resulting card file, which was typed by Annie Lewis from Mabel Hurlbut's notes, is held by the Farmington Public Library. The cards, along with later survey worksheets, house photographs and other notes, are accessible through the library's website (http://farmingtonlibraries.org/farmington-homes/).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Father Joseph Leonard CM (1877-1964) was an Irish priest in the Catholic Vincentian Order who taught at St. Mary's College, a teacher training school run by the Vincentian order at Strawberry Hill in Twickenham. Leonard befriended the Lewises in the early 1930s, and their relationship continued after he returned to Ireland in 1939, to join the Vincentian seminary at All Hallows in Drumcondra, Dublin. Additional correspondence with him can be found in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The item here is a letter sent by Annie Burr Lewis while on a trip to Egypt.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Margolis Shop in Hartford specialized in the restoration of antique pieces and made reproduction furniture for clients including the Lewises.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The file contains documentation of the Thomas Clark writing table and other furniture pieces.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Terence Neill was the son of Katherine Livingston and Samuel Montaudevert Neill of New York; his grandfather, Edward M. Neill, had a summer home in Newport. An actor, Neill wrote just before his starring role with Bela Lugosi in the first American performance of Dracula .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents regarding a study of traffic on Main Street, Farmington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence regarding their friend Elizabeth Hudson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folders contain correspondence related to business, including letters from various vendors.

did.unittitle: Antiquarian & Landmarks Society, Inc. of Connecticut

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Christopher Tunnard.

did.unittitle: "View from the North / The Meeting House and Church School"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Birds-eye view of proposed addition to First Church by William and Jeffrey Platt, New York; rendering by Schell Lewis; graphite on paper mounted on pulp board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a copy of Theodate Pope Riddle's will.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Hroswitha Club was an organization of women book collectors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the material is related to the 1913 centennial celebrations.

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annie Lewis became Vice Regent for Connecticut in 1942; her certificate of appointment is in Series II (Box 54, folder 3). The files here hold correspondence with Rosamund Beirne and others, including outgoing letters that were returned to Wilmarth Lewis after Annie Lewis's death in 1959. The bulk of the material is comprised of various unpublished reports on the furnishings, gardens, and history of restorations at Mount Vernon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A typed transcript, with carbon copy, of an interview with Annie Lewis broadcast on Hartford radio station WTIC (Travelers Broadcasting Service), February 15, 1954.

did.unittitle: National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Annie Lewis was a member of the National Council for Zone 1 (New England).

did.unittitle: National Society for the Prevention of Blindness
Tercentenary Commission of the State of Connecticut
Faculty Committee for Receiving Oxford and Cambridge University Children

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Beginning in July 1940, the Yale Faculty Committee for Receiving Oxford and Cambridge University Children coordinated the wartime evacuation of wives of Oxford faculty members and their children to Connecticut. More than 125 mothers and children arrived in New Haven; Annie Lewis sponsored three families and provided housing and support in Farmington, taking a personal interest in their well-being during their time in Connecticut in addition to funding the children's education. Iris Johnston and Elizabeth Haslam-Jones, with their children, came under Mrs. Lewis's care. After Haslam-Jones returned to England in the spring of 1942, Irene Ewert and her two daughters took her place. The families were housed at 144 Main Street in Farmington.

Three other women, Katherine Burn, Brenda Clapham, Ruth McGregor, and their children also came to Farmington under the sponsorship of Robert Keep, the headmaster of Miss Porter's School and his wife RoseAnne.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Katherine Pemberton Burn, the wife of Joshua Harold Burn, Professor of Pharmacology, arrived in Farmington with her children Josephine, Margaret ("Molly"), Frances, and Robert.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Iris May Johnston, the wife of Edward Hamilton Johnston, Boden Professor of Sanskrit at Oxford, arrived with five of their six children: Felicity, Katherine, Veronica, Stephen, and Edward Alexander. Professor Johnston died in October 1942, while his family was living in Farmington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two issues of a "magazine" created by the British children living in Farmington; number 1 is a photostat copy, number 2 is a mimeograph copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot photographs of the English children, without captions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hand painted by Felicity Johnston at a camp in Milton, Vermont, in the summer of 1942.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into eight subseries: Appointment Calendars and Diaries; Awards, Certificates, and Honors; Cookbooks and Recipes; Research Materials; School Notebooks; Scrapbooks and Albums; Writings; and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds a variety of materials spanning Annie Lewis's life, including her certificates of her birth, baptism, and marriage, school notebooks, postcard albums, scrapbooks, diaries, passports, address books, family recipe books, and copies of her will. Also here are samples of her stationery and records of her purchase of the Hart-Deming house, known as the "Red House," in Farmington that she restored and donated to Miss Porter's School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers two trips: New York-Edinburgh-Strathpeffer-London-New York (1913), and New York-Niagara Falls-Seattle-Western Canada-Montreal-Boston-Newport (1915).

did.unittitle: Itinerary of a trip to France, Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of Corine Roosevelt Robinson to Annie Lewis, and featuring a poem by her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six small notebooks, one dated on cover "March 1931," in which Annie Lewis recorded her dreams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small personal appointment books, the same type as used by Wilmarth Lewis (LWL MSS 20, Boxes 262-263), but are here only for the years 1936, 1938, 1939, 1944, 1949, and 1957.

The pictorial weekly desk calendars kept by Annie Lewis from 1940 until her death in 1959 were continued after her death by Wilmarth Lewis or household staff members. They are filed in the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 20), Boxes 264-265.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate for "Elementary Hygiene and Home Care of the Sick" issued after a series of classes taken in New York; with Annie Lewis's autograph outline/notes.

did.unittitle: Connecticut Society of the Colonial Dames of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Life membership certificate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Appointment as Vice Regent for the State of Connecticut

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Resolution in gratitude for the Annie Burr Lewis Fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Membership certificate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filed here is a resolution for Annie Lewis's appointment as Curator of Prints at the Lewis Walpole Library.

did.unittitle: Alumnae Association of Miss Porter's School, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Posthumous citation to honor her founding the association in 1937.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small three-ring binder with typed recipes and clipped recipes taped on lined pages; some recipes annotated by Annie Lewis. Inserted between the pages are mimeographed sheets of recipes issued by the Home Institute of the New York Herald Tribune .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Annie Lewis's recipe book was given to Rebecca Sherrill More by Wilmarth Lewis in 1972; she returned it to the library in 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A set of index cards with typed recipes.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Annie Lewis's recipe file was given to Rebecca Sherrill More by Wilmarth Lewis in 1972; she returned it to the library in 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three-ring binder holding typed recipes following a cover sheet with a note in Annie Lewis's hand: "Grandmother Auchincloss's Cook-book (Elizabeth Buck Auchincloss) 1816-1902, the original owned by the late Dr. Hugh Auchincloss. Some of the later entries in the book came from my mother Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss." Inserted in back pocket is a separate booklet: "Copies of Recipes (Mary Finnegan) Aunt Annie Burr Jennings' cook."
A second notebook is a typed copy of the first.

did.unittitle: Notes on book history, collation, and cataloging

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph and typed notes from a course/courses on the history of printing, manuscripts, and creating catalog records.

did.unittitle: Address book for the eighteenth century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small address book in which Annie Lewis entered names, life dates, addresses, and brief biographies of people in Horace Walpole's circle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prints examined at the Fitzwilliam Museum, Dunster Castle, and Sir John Soane Museum.

did.unittitle: Notes on botanical prints and drawings

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Annie Burr Auchincloss attended Miss Porter's School for three academic years, 1917-1920.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains four commercial albums and two scrapbooks. The albums hold unsent postcards collected by Annie Lewis on her travels and those she received from family and friends. Because they are fastened to the pages in her arrangement, the cards were unable to be analyzed for content, but it appears that many were sent to Annie by her aunt Annie Burr Jennings (1855-1939). The span dates of albums were determined by postal frankings or datelines that could be easily seen without damaging the cards or pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcards from friends and family, primarily holiday cards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcards primarily collected on trips to France and Italy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcards collected on trips to England, and received from traveling friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcards collected on trip from Niagara Falls to western Canada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers Esther Auchincloss's wedding to Edmund Nash (1917), and social activities in Newport, New York, and New Haven.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers activities at Miss Porter's School; contains printed ephemera, notes and letters from friends, and five pages of photographs of students. Much of the memorabilia relates to theatrical activities at the school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily the prepared remarks delivered at their wedding anniversary events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Memoir of her "Aunt Ellie."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a photograph as an infant and manuscript entries made through October 1903.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph book signed by family and friends from 1911-1929.

did.unittitle: Baptism certificate, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church
Daisy from marshal staff (Miss Porter's School)
Munson Steamship Lines "Order of the Trident" certificates for travel on the SS American Legion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The certificates were issued to Annie and Wilmarth Lewis while onboard the steamship SS American Legion , which carried passengers and cargo in Munson's South American service. The Lewises began their honeymoon in to (or from) Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

did.unittitle: Souvenir postcard and photograph books from Rio de Janeiro

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lewises traveled to Brazil on the first part of their honeymoon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small blank book with a mirror and pencil, in a paper case; inscribed on the second leaf, "Mrs. Wray's Present to her Husband" and below that, "Mr. Lewis's present to his wife. London April 1928." Mr. Wray is possibly Sir Cecil Wray (1734-1805). The mirror was broken when found (2017).

did.unittitle: Address books for London, Paris, and New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three leather-bound address books in a leather-covered case.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The "Red House" was purchased by Annie Lewis in 1930, rented out as a bookshop in the 1930s, and given to Miss Porter's School in the late 1940s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files hold deeds and other records regarding repairs, paint colors, and renovations, including blueprints for a doorway and fireplace moulding by New Haven architect Douglas Orr. Also present is a May 15, 1930, issue of the Farmington Valley Herald with a related article about the use of part of the property for a proposed fire station.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The file holds Carl Rollins's original artwork for a bookplate he designed for Annie Lewis, with a sample of a bookplate of a different design using Rollins's lettering.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Funeral service program and newspaper clipping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Samples of her printed letter paper, postcards, calling cards, mailing label, and paper hang tag.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains licenses and recommended diets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning storage and disposition of furs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mailing bags, negative and print wallets and envelopes, and other ephemera from the Pavelle Laboratories and Eastman Kodak companies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dance card from Cambridge University social, membership cards, and other ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Watercolor and graphite sketches of figures, landscapes, and the New Library (exterior).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into three subseries: Genealogical Materials, Emma Brewster Jennings Auchincloss Papers, and Annie Burr Jennings Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of three groups of material: genealogical records of the Auchincloss, Burr, Jennings, and Nash families; papers of Emma Brewster Jennings Auchincloss; and papers of Annie Burr Jennings. The latter two groups contain some correspondence, ephemera, and Emma Auchincloss's photograph album from her time at Miss Porter's School. Also present are estate records for the Jennings sisters that include detailed inventories of their three homes in Connecticut and New York City; the inventories provide an important window on the material culture environment in which Annie Lewis was raised, as well as a record of the furnishings and decorative objects she brought into her own two homes after their deaths.

did.unittitle: Auchincloss family genealogy and other notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two printed family trees, possibly removed from a publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Family chart drawn and illuminated by Charles L. N. Camp of New Haven, an artist and professional genealogist who specialized in designing and producing coats-of-arms and family charts. It traces the family from Jehue Burr (1625-1692) to Annie Burr Auchincloss, and encompasses the Goodsell, Jennings, and ten other families related by marriage, all represented by family crests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two printed fan charts published by Frank Farnsworth Starr of Middletown, Connecticut, and filled with names in an unidentified hand; one register was created for Annie Burr Jennings and one for Emma Jennings Auchincloss.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Emma Brewster Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942), a philanthropist, was the mother of Annie Lewis. The second of the five children of Oliver Burr Jennings and Esther Judson Goodsell Jennings, she was born in San Francisco, raised in New York and Fairfield, Connecticut, attended Miss Porter's School, and married a New York merchant, Hugh D. Auchincloss (1858-1913), in 1891. The couple raised their son and two daughters in New York and Newport, Rhode Island. Some years after her husband's death, Emma Auchincloss built a home, Dormy House on Sasco Hill Road in Fairfield, Connecticut, and died there at the age of 80.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Likely assembled by Emma Jennings, the album begins with images of Farmington, Connecticut, followed by images of Sarah Porter, her school, students, class pictures, and reunions; and an image of the Memento Mori Cemetery cenotaph erected in memory Porter School art instructor Sarah Strong Tuthill (1830-1882). Following a series of blank leaves, a second group of ten pages of photographs of young women begins with a photograph of Celia Jennings. A third grouping of twenty-four pages begins with images of Fairfield, family scenes, pictures of dogs, sail boats, horse and buggies, pictures of interiors, groups of friends and family (some people are identified).
Bound in three-quarters green morocco; spine split.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Former call number: LWL Mss Vol. 201

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters to Emma Auchincloss from the Farmington Lodge Society (Miss Porter's School) and the Kingsley Trust Association regarding the death of Hugh D. Auchincloss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records kept, in an unknown hand, of stocks purchased and sold for members of the Jennings, Auchincloss, and Lewis families

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from hospital staff enclosing a letter from a French soldier occupying the bed endowed by Emma Auchincloss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph of a library dedication plaque listing Emma Auchincloss as a donor. (2018: plaque is in storage at the LuEsther T. Mertz Library.)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The gravestone is in Oaklawn Cemetery, Fairfield, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inventory of furniture received by the Lewises from the Auchincloss house in Fairfield, Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Annie Burr Jennings (1855-1939) was an aunt of Annie Lewis, and the eldest of the five children of Oliver Burr Jennings and Esther Judson Goodsell Jennings. Born in San Francisco and raised in Fairfield, Connecticut, she attended Fairfield Academy and Miss Porter's School. Annie Jennings never married, and devoted her life to family, collecting, and history, with a particular interest in eighteenth-century American history. She served for many years as Vice Regent for Connecticut in the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union, a position to which she was nominated by her friend William Howard Taft. She filled her two homes in New York City and in Fairfield with her collections of prints, books, china, and silver; the latter residence, called "Sunnie-Holme," was noted for its extensive gardens which were open to the public. Jennings was a renowned philanthropist in both New York and Connecticut, and died at Sunnie-Holme at the age of 83.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, ephemera, and Annie Jennings's 1915 certificate appointing her Vice Regent of the State of Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding Goodsell genealogy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A group of disparate letters from friends and colleagues to Jennings, with a Christmas greeting from Sunnie-Holme.

did.unittitle: Annie Burr Jennings Ancestral Notes, I to XLI

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript volume of biographies and genealogy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mounted photographs of Aaron Burr portraits by Gilbert Stuart, John Vanderlyn (2), James Van Dyck, and Henry Inman, and a Theodosia Burr Alston portrait by John Vanderlyn (1811). The photographs were formerly in frames and each has a typed description from John E. Stillwell's book The History of the Burr Portraits (1928).

did.unittitle: Diary of a trip to Italy

unittitle.title: List of Shrubs and Plants…grown in Sunnie-Holme Herb Garden

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript notes in one volume of about one hundred cooking recipes for breads, pastries, sandwiches, and meat dishes. Pasted in at the end of the volume are fifteen pages of recipes cut from newspapers. The volume is inscribed inside the front cover: "Annie B Jennings / 1875."

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Former call number: LWL Mss Vol. 13

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Embossed paper and satin valentine with a letter dated August 1849, both addressed to "Mr. Shipman" enclosed in an early twentieth-century envelope stating the letter was "supposedly written" by Esther Judson Goodsell.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Howard Taft was a student at Yale with Walter Jennings (1858–1933), the brother of Annie and Emma Jennings, and both men were members of Skull and Bones. Taft also taught at Yale from 1913 until he joined the United States Supreme Court in 1921.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letters, and typed letters, signed, from Taft to Annie Jennings; also present is one letter from Helen Taft.

did.unittitle: Banquet program, Yale University graduates dinner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The dinner was held at the Waldorf Astoria in New York; inscribed: "For Miss Annie Jennings / with affectionate regard of Wm H. Taft / March 19-1909."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A mounted half-length portrait by Isaac Benjamin, Cincinnati; inscribed on mount below image: "For my friend Miss Annie Jennings / with best wishes / Wm H Taft"; in a double-sided display frame made by D. B. Butler & Co., New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A half-length portrait of Benito Mussolini mounted on a sheet of card; he is holding a sheaf of paper. "FOT V LAVIOSA/ROMA" is printed in the upper left corner. "CONCESS PANDIMIGLIO-38 CAFO LE CASE-ROMA" is printed at the lower left and "REPRODUZIONE VIRTATA-DEPOSITATA" is printed at the lower right. Inscribed in ink on the card mount: "A Miss Annie Burr / Roma marzo 1927 V Mussolini."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into two subseries: Bank Accounts, and Investment Accounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds both Annie Lewis's checking account records and those of her investments managed by her brother Hugh D. Auchincloss and members of his firm Auchincloss, Parker & Redpath. The bulk of the series is comprised of check registers from the two New York banks and one Hartford bank she patronized from the 1920s until her death. Also here are the registers from the Lewises' years living in Washington, D.C. When available, cancelled checks were retained to fill some gaps where check registers could not be found when the papers were processed in 2017-2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annie Lewis's check registers document her life and lifestyle; checks were recorded by Lewis or her assistant Gertrude Manly, and show expenses for taxes, dogs, automobiles, and staff; payment of dues and house tabs in private clubs in New York, Connecticut, and Rhode Island; and contributions to charities in those states. Many of the checks were written for purchases in shops such as Hartford's G. Fox, and New York's Henri Bendel, Bonwit Teller, Hammacher Schlemmer, and Steuben Glass, as well as for goods and services received from the Hartford decorators Maritje Jacobus and Henry Saling, and furniture maker Nathan Margolis, and the decorator Elizabeth Draper in New York. Another regular expense was photography, and many checks were written to Pavelle Laboratories for developing film and printing the pictures taken by Annie Lewis that appear throughout the Lewises' photograph collection (LWL MSS 22).

did.unittitle: Farmers' Loan and Trust Company (New York, N.Y.)
National City Bank of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lacking registers covering February to August 1931, and January 1932 to March 1933.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lacking registers covering January to May 1936, and October 1936 to May 1937. Folder 1 holds a register for a pocket checkbook that Annie Lewis used from July 1936 through September 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lacking register covering October to December 1937.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lacking register covering July to November 1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lacking registers covering January 1951 to March 1955.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lacking register covering mid-June 1957 to October 1957, and January-March 1959.

did.unittitle: Checkbooks and cancelled checks for London branch
Hartford National Bank and Trust Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records of trust accounts set up for Hugh and Agnes Ross, Lily Duncan, Helen M. Scarth, and the Sarah Porter Centenary Fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small loose-leaf notebook with Julia McCarthy's notes on interest earned.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Connecticut Camp and Hospital Committee, and Other Papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Lewises moved to Washington, DC, in the fall of 1941 when Wilmarth Lewis accepted an appointment as chief of the Information Division in the Office of Strategic Services. Upon arrival, Annie Lewis offered her services to the National Headquarters of the American Red Cross. She held two positions with the organization: assistant director of Volunteer Special Services (1941-1944) and, once she returned to Farmington in 1943, as a Volunteer Field Representative for Camp and Hospital Service, (1944-1946).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series primarily contains records from Annie Lewis's service in Connecticut (1944-1946), and includes copies of memos and reports sent from and to the North Atlantic Office in New York. Also here are reports she wrote after her visits to cities and towns around the state, as well as correspondence about programs and events being organized for veterans.
The contents of the files were not arranged; the papers were rehoused in 2018 and titles from the original files were repurposed for this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with the North Atlantic Office in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a map of Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As the state of Connecticut's representative, Annie Lewis received copies of all monthly reports issued by chapters around the state.

did.unittitle: Council Field Representative Chapter Visit reports
Services to the Armed Forces memos
Red Cross badges, button, and other uniform items

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Annie Lewis in a group photograph taken at the Red Cross convention in Los Angeles, 1943, and volunteers posing with actor Walter Pidgeon. Her official portrait photographs are filed in the Lewises' photograph collection (LWL MSS 22), Box 5, Folder 10.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an article on Annie Lewis published in the Washington Star, October 15, 1942.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issues of the Camp and Hospitals Councils newsletter for February, August, September, and December 1944, with editorial policy memo.

did.unittitle: Suggestions for Conducting Meetings , by Sarah Corbin Robert

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Booklet published for the use of Volunteer Special Services.
